description: From Middle English chateren, from earlier cheteren, chiteren (“to twitter, chatter, jabber”), of imitative origin. Compare Saterland Frisian tjoaterje (“to chatter”), West Frisian tsjotterje (“to chatter”), Dutch schateren, schetteren (“chatter”), Dutch koeteren (“jabber”), dialectal German kaudern (“to gobble (like a turkey)”), Danish kvidre (“to twitter, chirp”).

entries.meaning: Talk, especially meaningless or unimportant talk.
examples: Synonyms: chattering, chatting, nattering; see also Thesaurus:chatter

entries.meaning: The vocalisations of a Eurasian magpie, Pica pica.
The vocalisations of various birds or other animals.
examples: The wind rose as the earth darkened, so that fading chatters of woodland animals were countered by the strengthening sounds of waving trees  […]

entries.meaning: An intermittent noise, as from vibration.
examples: Proper brake adjustment will help to reduce the chatter.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) In national security, the degree of communication between suspect groups and individuals, used to gauge the degree of expected terrorist activity.
examples: The NSA is concerned about increased chatter between known terror groups.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The situation where a drill or similar tool vibrates and tears the material rather than cutting it cleanly.

verbs.description: chatter (third-person singular simple present chatters, present participle chattering, simple past and past participle chattered)

examples: They knitted and chattered the whole time.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of teeth, machinery, etc.) To make a noise by rapid collisions.
examples: Synonyms: clatter, knock, (said of an engine) pink
He was so cold that his teeth were chattering.

entries.meaning: To utter sounds which somewhat resemble language, but are inarticulate and indistinct.
